text: Sorry, I didn't get a chance to message you yesterday

Basically I'm here to help you out wherever you need, advice on getting in to the industry/any questions you may have, give feedback/tips on any uni and personal work etc, career paths, help with applications, whatever you need really. 

Is there anything you're particularly looking to get out of this?

I want to become a compositor at a big studio like framestore so if you can share any tips on how to get my first steps in the industry, how you got to work at framestore and what a studio like framestore wants in a showreel from a junior compositor.

First things first is to recognise how to get in to a big studio. You will never start out as a junior compositor at a big studio or pretty much any studio. It is possible at small, boutique places but I wouldn't reccomend it personally. Most compositors at Framestore will have either been a runner or in paint and roto (most will have done both) as they are the entry level jobs to get to comp. I would start practicing your roto and get a really good reel with high level roto and some paint as that is what we look for in applications for paint roto artists. 

I took a bit of a different route to most people. I was the first VFX apprentice, there was 5 of us and it is run by NextGen but as you've gone to uni it's a bit late for that but is a great way in. I didn't have to be a runner and went straight to paint roto and quickly developed in to a lead and then on in to comp
Ok a big question that i have is where do you think i can get these difficults shots for roto and paint?

There's lots of plates out there but it is tough to find them. There's a few options, there is Hollywood camera works, blender projects (they offer free plates), fxphd, pluralsight, etc plates, unpaid projects

Personally I think inpaid projects are the best for this type of stuff as if possible you should try stay away from tutorial shots that everyone has in there reel. You need to stand out and show you put in more effort than others
But before you take on shots on somebodys project you need to be pretty good already. So that's where you should use tutorial sites, stuff you shot yourself etc to practice your skills
ok i will start doing tutorials on some roto, paint and keying and if i need help ill message you.  Thanks.
For sure. I'll send you some links to good ones when I get the chance
When you've done a shot feel free to send it over for me to review? Then I can give you notes/say it looks great. Otherwise it's quite tricky to know if it's good enough yourself
Let me know if you have any difficulties
Id recommend starting with roto, that's much more important
Are there certain times where its best to message you because i dont want to bombard you with messages when you are busy or when its late.
Any time is fine don't worry. If I'm going to do something it'll be late in the evening when I'm home from work but I can message any time. If I'm busy I won't reply, don't worry
When i roto, how do i see the the black and white alpha. I have been searching but i cant find the answer.
